Jonathan Adler: Manifesting the Manifesto

12 Nov 2009

Creating a succinct statement of your company’s  purpose can seem like a tedious, unnecessary task. Typically, creating a Mission Statement involves folks holding up for days on a corporate retreat, just to come up with some useless blather that hangs on a plaque in the reception area.

Have a look at Jonathan Adler’s Manifesto. It is *not *a Mission Statement. In fact, it is the anti-Mission Statement. It is a treatise overflowing with funny, kitchy, and frankly inspiring stuff like “We believe that when it comes to decorating, the wife is always right. Unless the husband is gay.” and “We believe handcrafted tchotchkes are life-enhancing.” By the end I’m gushing and ready to proclaim “He’s right goddamn it. He’s right!”

This is exactly what a Manifesto is intended to do. In fact, the word Manifesto is Latin for “clear or evident.” In her blog post on the subject, Jennifer Rice makes the point that the Manifesto is for everyone: “it’s a public declaration, not something that’s limited to employees. Everyone sees it.” And as a result it doesn’t feature “vague, self-serving statements.”

Jonathan Adler’s Manifesto is bereft of corporate-speak. And, because it is makes his purpose clear, it is the perfect elixir for those cynical types. Those of us who thought that seeing Jonathan Adler and his stuff everywhere including a recently designed Barbie Collection (which he says “allowed him to finally make amends for decapitating sister’s Barbie in 1974.”) and his role on reality show Top Design made him a big, fat sell-out.

He stands for one thing and that is the first point in his Manifesto “Your home should make you happy.” His ubiquity is a reflection of his democratic approach to design. If you didn’t get it before, you sure get it after 22 pithy points. And, if you didn’t get it the first time, he hits you over the head with his 10 Commandments of Happy Chic. His only use of exalted language is  his use of Thou and Thy which is entirely ironic.

Here’s what you can take from Jonathan Adler’s Manifesto:

  • Be Clear: Cut out any word that sounds like marketing/corporate speak. Say it like you’re talking to your best-friend
  • *Get a Personality: *Get one and infuse everything you do with that special sauce
  • *Be Audacious: *Don’t be afraid of sticking your neck out or starting a fight. At the height of the minimalism, Adler used his Manifesto to  declare minimalism “a bummer”
  • Follow-Through: Walk the Walk. Once you read his Manifesto you totally get why Adler sells banana Xmas ornaments and  banana bud vases both for under $50
  • *Declare It Again and Again: *He tells you what he’s about 10 ways to Sunday. It’s all over his site, it’s in all his interviews. He’s living the Manifesto.

Here’s a list of other brands that have written kick-ass Manifestos that are great examples to look to:

  • Chipotle’s Food With Integrity Manifesto
  • Lance Armstrong Livestrong Foundation (it is also the form of a video)
  • Bruce Mau Design Incomplete Manifesto for Growth

About us

Hypenotic is a marketing strategy, design & development firm that chooses to use its powers for good. We’re a certified founding member of B Corp in Canada, and if you don’t know what that is, it’s time you do. Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
